awd_titl_txt: BTT EAGER:   Mitotic Recombination between Homologous Chromosomes
awd_abstract_narration:
All the individuals of a given species carry the same genes.  What makes one individual different from another is its unique combination of alleles (versions) of those genes.  By crossing plants carrying different sets of alleles, crop breeders can create new crop varieties, with new combinations of alleles. However, because genes are clustered together on chromosomes, a desirable allele of one gene may be located very close to an undesirable allele of another gene on the same chromosome.  The close clustering, or linkage of genes means that both the desirable and undesirable alleles are inherited together. This research provides tools that allow the plant breeder to separate or replace alleles of linked genes. This technology accelerates the rate at which new and improved crop varieties can be produced. This is an important goal, as the development of new crop varieties is an ongoing race with the evolution of new varieties of pathogens, increasing demand from an expanding world population, unpredictable climate, and the degradation of existing farmland. Food security -worldwide, not just at home- is an essential aspect of our national security.

CRISPR technologies provide a remarkably specific and efficient means for the generation of targeted DNA double strand breaks (DSBs) in plants. Error-prone end-to-end joining of CRISPR induced breaks can generate targeted mutations and translocations; repair via homologous recombination (HR) can create new alleles or new combinations of alleles.  CRISPR-induced HR events are relatively rare in plants.  Tools developed here proposal improve the efficiency of HR. While this technology applies to any HR-dependent event, specifically interest is in the facilitation of recombination between endogenous preexisting alleles. This technology greatly enhances the speed and specificity of the development of new plant lines, both for breeding and for research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

Most crops, like people, carry two sets of chromosomes, one set inherited from each parent. While each parent carries the same genes, they may carry different versions (termed “alleles”) of those genes. New crop varieties are generated through the crossing of different parents with different good qualities, resulting in random, new combinations of alleles, and so new combinations of qualities. Breeders then select for new varieties with desirable, heritable traits. Because genes are present in linear order on chromosomes, alleles of 2 genes that are located closely together on the chromosome are almost always inherited together. This may make it difficult or impossible for the breeder to separate a useful version of gene A from a physically linked, toxic version of gene B. The goal of this project was to determine whether it is possible to employ CRISPR technology (which literally breaks chromosomes at specific sites chosen by the breeder) in combination with certain DNA repair defects (which affect the way in which broken chromosomes are repaired) to encourage “recombination” (the reciprocal exchange of segments of chromosomes) between the maternal and paternal versions of a chromosome- at specific sites. This would result in the replacement of, for instance, the toxic allele of gene B on the paternal chromosome with a beneficial allele of gene B found on the maternal chromosome, creating a new, very useful “recombinant” chromosome. In addition to achieving this applied goal, our work will provide insight into the mechanism through which chromosomes broken by CRISPR are repaired.

We have created several of the desired repair mutants (in tomato and the model plant Arabidopsis), learned that some of these repair defects result in sterility in tomato (unlike Arabidopsis), identified and/or created chromosomal targets that will allow us to determine whether we have induced recombination between chromosomes, and created stocks that carry the CRISPR genes designed to cut at those specific targets. Ongoing work includes creating tomato and Arabidopsis stocks that carry all of these resources in the right combinations to allow us to test our hypothesis. 

A series of undergraduate volunteer researchers participated in this project, gaining skills in basic plant genetics, molecular identification of mutations and transgenes, the assembly of transgenes, design of CRISPR guide RNAs, and transformation of Arabidopsis.
